headline: Asia Session Closes Red as Bitcoin Tests $90K

sections.the_session:
• Bitcoin slipped below $90,500 during Hong Kong afternoon trading, briefly touching $90,189 before finding tentative support — a level that marked the floor of last week's consolidation range and now faces its first serious test since the post-election rally.

• Ethereum's 1.5% decline proved relatively contained compared to the broader altcoin complex, with ETH maintaining the $3,100 handle while Solana bore the brunt of risk-off positioning, shedding 4.4% as traders rotated out of higher-beta exposure.

• Total market capitalisation contracted by $64 billion to $3.16 trillion, though BTC dominance held steady at 57% — suggesting the pullback reflects broad de-risking rather than any specific rotation between assets.

• Liquidation data showed $180 million in long positions unwound over the past 12 hours, concentrated in the Asian afternoon session, though the figure remains modest by recent standards and suggests orderly repositioning rather than forced selling.
sections.the_session_title: Bitcoin Surrenders Ground on Light Volume
sections.the_macro:
• The DXY dollar index extended gains into a third consecutive session, pressing toward 107 as traders recalibrated Fed rate cut expectations following last week's hawkish minutes — a headwind for risk assets that has proven particularly acute for crypto in recent cycles.

• US spot Bitcoin ETFs recorded their first net outflow day in two weeks on Friday, with $240 million leaving the products ahead of the weekend — a data point that filtered through Asian sentiment as Monday trading commenced.

• Treasury yields stabilised after Friday's moves, with the 10-year holding near 4.42%, though the curve's persistent inversion continues to signal recession concerns that complicate the institutional case for risk-on positioning.

• Oil's slide below $69 on demand concerns added another deflationary signal to the macro picture, creating a mixed backdrop where lower energy costs support consumer spending but weaker growth expectations temper risk appetite.
sections.the_macro_title: Dollar Strength and Rate Expectations Weigh

east_asia.name: East Asia
east_asia.content:
• Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission confirmed it will publish updated guidance on stablecoin regulation before year-end, with industry participants expecting a framework that mirrors the city's existing virtual asset licensing regime — potentially positioning HK-issued stablecoins as compliant alternatives for institutional flows.

• South Korean exchanges reported elevated weekend volumes despite the price decline, with Upbit's won-denominated Bitcoin premium narrowing to 1.2% from last week's 2.8% — a compression that typically signals reduced retail urgency and more measured institutional participation.

• Japan's Metaplanet disclosed an additional 124 BTC purchase at an average price of $96,000, bringing its treasury holdings to 1,142 BTC as the Tokyo-listed firm continues its MicroStrategy-inspired accumulation strategy despite near-term price weakness.

• Chinese state media ran unusual coverage of Bitcoin's approach to $100,000 last week, maintaining the critical editorial line but acknowledging the milestone's significance — a shift in tone that mainland crypto observers noted as potentially meaningful for future policy signalling.

southeast_asia.name: Southeast Asia
southeast_asia.content:
• Singapore's Monetary Authority issued a reminder to licensed exchanges regarding customer asset segregation requirements, following up on November inspections — routine compliance activity, but the timing amid market volatility underscores the city-state's emphasis on operational resilience.

• Thailand's SEC approved a second batch of four retail crypto funds, expanding the regulated investment product landscape as the regulator balances its historically cautious stance with growing domestic demand for compliant exposure vehicles.

• Vietnam's central bank reiterated that cryptocurrencies remain outside the legal payment framework, though the statement notably omitted previous language discouraging ownership — a subtle but potentially significant softening that local industry groups highlighted.

• Philippine remittance corridor volumes through crypto rails reached a monthly record in November according to Coins.ph data, with the peso's weakness against the dollar driving increased adoption of stablecoin-based transfers from overseas workers.

oceania.name: Oceania
oceania.content:
• Australia's Treasury confirmed that consultation on the proposed digital asset licensing framework will extend into Q1 2025, pushing back expected implementation timelines but allowing additional industry input on custody and exchange requirements.

• The Australian dollar's slide to 64.5 US cents — its lowest since October 2023 — created arbitrage opportunities on local exchanges, with brief premiums appearing on AUD-denominated pairs before normalising during afternoon trading.

• New Zealand's Financial Markets Authority published updated guidance clarifying that staking services fall under existing financial product definitions, a classification that will require several local platforms to adjust their offerings or seek additional licensing.

image_keywords: dusk, city skyline, muted tones, overcast
